Log Overview

Table of Contents

  • Introduction
  • Logging Classes
  • Thread Safety
  • Configuring the Logger to write a single output file
  • Configuring the Logger via JSON


Introduction

An application typically configures its logging on startup. From then on, all logging calls made by the process will behave as configured.

Examples:

  • Configuring the Logger to write a single output file (simplest case)
  • Configuring the Logger via JSON (flexible case)


Logging Classes

  • IonicSecurity::SDK::LogFactory
  • IonicSecurity::SDK::Log
  • IonicSecurity::SDK::LogBase


Thread Safety

All Log interfaces are thread-safe for use in concurrent threads. Most importantly, this means that writing log messages is thread-safe.


Configuring the Logger to write a single output file

This is the simplest way to create and configure a logger!

using IonicSecurity.SDK;
// create a logger that will write to a file named "MyLogFile.log", which will
// be opened in append mode, and will output log messages at INFO severity and
// above (this means INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL)
LogBase log = LogFactory.GetInstance.CreateSimple("MyLogFile.log", true, LogSeverity.SEV_INFO);
// set the logger to be the global logger
Log.SetSingleton(log);
// write a sample log (optional!)
Log.LogInfo("MyApplicationChannel", "We configured the logger successfully!");


Configuring the Logger via JSON

See Log Configuration from JSON for full documentation on the supported JSON configuration format. The JSON configuration may be provided by a string in memory or from a file on disk.

Configure from JSON file:

using IonicSecurity.SDK;
// create a logger from specified JSON configuration file
LogBase log = LogFactory.GetInstance.CreateFromConfigFile("MyConfigurationFile.json")
// set the logger to be the global logger
Log.SetSingleton(log);
// write a sample log (optional!)
Log.LogInfo("MyApplicationChannel", "We configured the logger successfully!");

Configure from JSON string:

using IonicSecurity.SDK;
// create a logger from specified JSON configuration string
LogBase log = LogFactory.GetInstance.CreateFromConfig("<Your JSON configuration here>");
// set the logger to be the global logger
Log.SetSingleton(log);
// write a sample log (optional!)
Log.LogInfo("MyApplicationChannel", "We configured the logger successfully!");
